repnme.cdata!:
Cambodia - Forest Concession Management and
            Control Pilot Project : third progress report to the Board
            of Executive Directors on implementation of
            management's action plan in response to the inspection
            panel investigation report

abstracts.cdata!:
On March 30, 2006, the inspection panel
            submitted its investigation on the Cambodia: Forest
            Concession Management and Control Pilot Project (FCMCPP) to
            the Board. On May 16, 2006, Management submitted its report
            and recommendations in response to the inspection
            panel's Investigation report. Since the project closed
            before the inspection panel report was completed, no
            project-specific actions were possible. Management's
            action plan therefore acknowledged the inherent and
            continuing challenges to increasing public participation in
            the forest sector in Cambodia, and laid out a strategic and
            forward-looking agenda to support the development of a more
            equitable and socially-inclusive approach to natural
            resources management. The Management action plan included
            specific actions to be taken at two levels: (a) across the
            Bank to mainstream improvements in environmental screening
            and classification and to expand the use of strategic
            environmental assessment with targeted training to
            familiarize Bank staff with these tools; and (b) by the
            within the region (EAP) to complete: (1) community
            consultation guidelines; and (2) the legal and regulatory
            framework for indigenous peoples' land rights in
            Cambodia. Recognizing that a sustained effort will be
            required, the management action plan also included a section
            outlining a phased approach to building a broad consensus
            with Government and other development partners on the way
            forward in the forestry sector. The present report follows
            the structure of the original action plan, detailing recent
            progress and challenges in the text and summarizing progress
            since June 2006 in table form.

repnme.cdata!:
Cambodia - Forest Concession Management and
            Control Pilot Project : progress report on the inspection
            panel investigation report

abstracts.cdata!:
The present report is intended to
            provide information to the Board regarding the progress in
            implementing the Action Plan of the Management Report of the
            Forest Concession Management and Control Pilot Project of
            Cambodia. Since the project closed before the Inspection
            Panel Report was completed, no project-specific actions were
            possible. Management's Action Plan took a pragmatic
            approach, however, recognizing the inherent and ongoing
            challenges to increasing public participation in the forest
            sector in Cambodia while at the same time laying out a
            strategic and forward looking agenda for dialogue and
            exploration of new approaches to develop more equitable and
            socially responsible natural resources management. This
            report outlines progress in both dialogue and implementation
            of the Bank's program in natural resources management
            (NRM), but also attempts to provide a realistic assessment
            of the continuing challenges as the Bank works with
            Cambodian Government counterparts to strengthen the legal
            and policy framework, overcome the inherent difficulties of
            working on issues requiring a high degree of
            inter-ministerial coordination and communication, and most
            importantly, close the large gaps between the legal and
            policy framework and what is actually happening at the field
            level in respect to forestry.

repnme.cdata!:
Cambodia - Agricultural Productivity
            Improvement ; Northeast Village Development ; Forest
            Concession Management and Control ; and Flood Emergency Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The principal ratings for the Cambodia
            Agricultural Productivity Improvement; Northeast Village
            Development; Forest Concession Management and Control; and
            Flood Emergency Projects are as follows: the outcome was
            moderately unsatisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was significant, the Bank performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory, and the borrower performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory. Some of the lessons learned from the project
            include the following: in the future, the use of learning
            instrument loans (LILs) or any instrument that circumvents
            any of the usual safeguard investigation during preparation
            should be subject not only to the normal tests of
            eligibility, but also the test o f downside risks, be these
            technical or the likelihood of adverse public opinion; where
            the client is not familiar with Bank operations and
            procedures or is confronting serious impediments to its
            ability to act on that knowledge, continuous presence of
            competent Bank representatives is a critical factor in
            moving dialogue and operations forward; when ambiguity or
            disagreements arise in implementation, particularly with the
            evolving focus or importance of an activity, an agreed
            strategy can become an effective management tool;
            institutions generally respond more favorably to moderate or
            gradual change than to radical innovation, particularly when
            power or stature are being threatened; and finally, while
            fiduciary accountability requires correct procedures and
            oversight, the development impact o f the Bank's
            approach to the issue is very much linked to the sensitivity
            with which it introduces the qualities of transparency and
            cost-effectiveness as desirable qualities in procurement transactions.

repnme.cdata!:
Cambodia - Forest Concession Management and
            Control Pilot Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Forest Concession
            Management and Control Pilot Project of Cambodia were as
            follows: outcomes were unsatisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was significant, the Bank performance
            was moderately unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance
            was moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: (a) The project design was based on optimistic
            views of the speed with which the Borrower's
            performance could be enhanced; (b) The projects design
            under-estimated the difficulties of working with private
            sector partners (concessionaires) who had signed contracts
            with the government before the project was conceived; (c)
            When the original basis for consensus amongst partners in a
            very difficult and sensitive sector erodes - for any reason
            - it is better to pause and work to rebuild some level of
            consensus than to charge ahead in the absence of that
            agreement; (d) The potential for technical assistance to
            lead to rapid improvements in practical capacity in the
            field for forest managers was overestimated; (e) The
            problems of working with a borrower agency whose staff did
            not have appropriate incentives to pursue project goals were
            under-estimated; (f) The difficulties of applying learning
            or introducing innovations in a LIL of this type were
            under-estimated; and (g) The situation can improve only if
            countries develop broad-based participatory institutions
            that offer equal voice to local constituencies, especially
            the vulnerable, and only if they can find the resources to
            forgo the short-term exploitation of forest.

repnme.cdata!:
Cambodia - Forest Concession Management and
            Control Pilot Project - Management Report and Recommendation
            in Response to the Inspection Panel Investigation Report

abstracts.cdata!:
This management Report and
            Recommendation responds to the Investigation Panel
            Inspection Report triggered by a Request for Inspection
            raised in connection with the Cambodia Forest Concession
            Management and Control Pilot Project. The Request for
            Inspection was submitted by the NGO Forum o f Cambodia
            acting on its own behalf and on behalf of affected local
            communities living in the districts of Tbeng Meanchey in
            Preah Vihear Province; Siem Bok and Sesan in Stung Treng
            Province; and Anlong Veng in Oddar Meanchey Province,
            Cambodia (the "Requesters"). Challenges to the
            project were focused on two key objectives: concessional
            planning and management, and forest crime monitoring and
            prevention. The Panel's findings, along with
            Management's responses, are described in detail in
            Annex 1. Management concludes that the Bank made every
            effort to apply its policies and procedures to pursue its
            mission statement in the context of the project; and
            specifically addresses the issues identified in Panel's
            Report in the section on Lessons learned and the proposed
            Action Plan. Among the specific actions it cites are
            proposals for: 1) reviewing and updating the
            "Guidelines for Environmental Screening and
            Classification" to provide additional guidance on
            classification and appropriate methods o f undertaking
            environmental and social safeguard related actions in
            technical assistance projects; 2) promoting the use of
            Strategic Environmental Assessments and related
            methodologies to help prepare and implement selected natural
            resources management projects to provide more information on
            baseline environmental and social trends and conditions; 3)
            taking steps to ensure that approaches, such as landscape
            level biodiversity management, best management practices for
            Protected Areas, and information-sharing are introduced in
            future projects o f this type; 4) supporting the
            finalization of the draft Community Consultation Guidelines
            in Cambodia; and ensuring that the Guidelines explicitly
            include a reference to the legal framework in Cambodia and
            provide guidance regarding the appropriate authorities to
            inform when "chance finds" occur; and 5)
            recognizing the urgency of securing land and resource rights
            for Indigenous Peoples in order to make a strong and
            immediate effort to collaborate with other donors and
            Government under the Technical Working group for Land, to
            finalize, as a matter o f priority, the legal and enabling
            implementing procedures required for making the provisions
            of the Land Law a reality for indigenous communities in Cambodia.

repnme.cdata!:
Cambodia - Forest Concession Management and
            Control Pilot Project : Inspection Panel Investigation Report

abstracts.cdata!:
This Investigation Report presents the
            Inspection Panel's findings from its investigation on
            the matters alleged in the Request for Inspection (see
            report no. 31576). The Panel found the following: In the
            project's focus on concessions, the Bank ignored or at
            least marginalized other aspects important to the Bank
            program in Cambodia and to the Government during the
            planning process. The project did not give adequate
            attention to vital interests of local communities and
            indigenous peoples in forest resources, and to the contested
            nature of forest domain. Rather the Bank gave primary
            emphasis in project design to the technical and financial
            aspects of concession reform at the expense of environmental
            and social aspects. The Panel also expressed concern, that
            certain parts of the guidelines about the concession review
            process developed under the project do not meet Bank
            safeguard policy requirements ad do not provide adequate
            framework for the Government to decide on any future
            forestry concessions. Unless this is remedied, the project
            will not achieve one of its main objectives to demonstrate
            and improve effectiveness of comprehensive forest management
            and operational guidelines in the forest concession area.
            The panel also addressed the choice of the Learning
            Innovation Loan (LIL) as a financing instrument;
            identification and protection of forests of high ecological
            value, of natural habitats, of the affected population and
            the project area, and of cultural property (spirit forests
            and archeological sites); the need for an environmental
            assessment, the project's environmental categorization;
            the need for a social assessment; impacts on local people of
            illegal logging of resin trees; consultations with affected
            people during project preparation; preparation of an
            indigenous peoples development plan; technical assistance
            that was provided; and the adequacy of Strategic Forest
            Management Plans (SFMP) and Environmental and Social Impact
            Assessments (ESIA).

repnme.cdata!:
Cambodia - Forest Concession Management and
            Control Pilot Project : Request for Inspection - Inspection
            Panel Report and Recommendation

abstracts.cdata!:
The Response provides background
            information on the Forest Concession Management and Control
            Pilot Project and discusses a number of challenges
            encountered during implementation, such as issues related to
            the logging concession systems and poor logging practices;
            log transport permits; a weak national forest revenue
            management system; and tensions among various stakeholders.
            The Response also discusses in detail the so-called special
            issues of this project (1) Bank approach to the forestry
            issues; (2) weakness in Cambodian governance institutions
            and (3) forestry management instruments. The Request and
            Management Response contain conflicting assertions and
            interpretations about the issues, the facts, and compliance
            with Bank policies and procedures. In light of the
            foregoing, the Panel recommends that an investigation be conducted.

repnme.cdata!:
Cambodia - Forest Concession Management and
            Control Pilot Project - Inspection Panel : Request for Inspection

abstracts.cdata!:
On January 28, 2005, the Inspection
            Panel (the 'Panel') received a Request for
            Inspection (the 'Request') related to the Cambodia
            - Forest Concession Management and Control Pilot Project.
            Enclosed herewith are: 1) A copy of the Notice o f
            Registration; and, 2) A copy o f the transmittal Memorandum
            to the President. The Requesters state that they have
            "received letters from a number of villagers, signed in
            March 2004" asking them "to represent their
            request ...." They also state that the "local
            community representatives who signed the letters have
            requested that their names be kept confidential." The
            Request includes two signed letters from representatives of
            affected communities, and a report prepared by the
            nongovernmental organization (NGO) Global Witness for the
            affected communities "providing details of the case and
            the violations of World Bank policies which occurred."
            The Requesters believe that "in its commissioning and
            supervision of the Project, the Bank has violated a number
            of its operational policies leading to harm or potential
            future harm to people living in the project-affected
            areas." In their view, the Project has "endorsed
            forest concession management plans of six forest concession
            companies" that "have a poor record with regard to
            the protection of community rights and livelihoods."
            Claims suggest that trees the villagers tap for resin will
            again be "cut illegally" when the logging
            activities resume, and that the villagers will be subject to
            the "kinds of abuses" they have suffered in the
            past. The Request has been assigned IPN Request Number RQ05/1.
